pr_title: [BEAM-2535] Support outputTimestamp and watermark holds in processing timers.

timeline.message: Updating Input and Output Watermarks for processing timers
Updating OnTimer, Removed equal checks in test cases

timeline.bodyText: I'm not sure that we need withOutputTimestampOffset - I think withOutputTimestamp is sufficient.
timeline.author: reuvenlax

timeline.bodyText: I think that we should verify that the output timestamp is > the timestamp of the input message (if in processElement) or the output timestamp of the firing timer (if in processTimer). The < check remains correct - even for processing-time timers.
timeline.author: reuvenlax

replies.bodyText: @reuvenlax , does that mean we need to compare output timestamp with timerInternal.currentInputWatermarkTime()? I think it will fail our previous test case of output timestamp with event timer as we have set output timestamp as 5 while having a timestamp of input element as 9.
replies.author: rehmanmuradali

timeline.bodyText: I think that if the timer is processing time, then then default outputTimestamp should be that of the input element (or the output time of the firing timer if in processTimer).
timeline.author: reuvenlax

timeline.message: Adding validation of output timestamp with respect to input element and firing timer

timeline.bodyText: I think this should be timestamp(), not fireTimestamp().
timeline.author: reuvenlax

timeline.bodyText: ditto - this should be timestamp() not fireTimestamp()
timeline.author: reuvenlax

timeline.bodyText: check outputTimestamp is in the window for processing-timer as well.
timeline.author: reuvenlax

timeline.bodyText: I think you want the second DoFn to set an event-time timer. That way you can test that the watermark hold in the first DoFn prevents firing of the second DoFn's timer, which it will only do if the second DoFn's timer is even time.
timeline.author: reuvenlax

timeline.bodyText: I don't think this is right. We want to fire timers based on firing time, not based on the hold.
timeline.author: reuvenlax

timeline.bodyText: I wonder if this is sufficient. The NavigableSet is ordered by timer firing time, not by outputTimestamp. This means that the logic to just look at the first timer (which was correct before we had holds) is probably no longer enough. we probably need to iterate over the set (or we need to have a second data structure to hold the watermark holds and take the minimum of that data structure).
timeline.author: reuvenlax

replies.bodyText: @reuvenlax  added a new function to calculate the earliest outputTimestamp from NavigableSet.
replies.author: rehmanmuradali

timeline.message: Input Element timestamp fix, processing timer after window validation, firing time fix, test case updates

timeline.bodyText: are we missing an else clause here?
timeline.author: reuvenlax

replies.bodyText: @reuvenlax  we only set outputTimestamp here. I think If that is already set before then we don't need anything. I think else clause is not required here.
replies.author: rehmanmuradali

timeline.author: reuvenlax

timeline.bodyText: check this before setting outputTimestamp above (and only if outputTimestamp != null)
timeline.author: reuvenlax
reuvenlax

timeline.bodyText:
I think you might have to advance processing time to at least 11.
You also need to advance the watermark to at least 10 to allow the timer to fire. Right now this isn't testing anything, because the input watermark is preventing the timer from firing.
timeline.author: reuvenlax

replies.bodyText: @reuvenlax, I think if we advance processing time to 11, it will fire fn1's timer as we have set delivery time offset as 10. If we advance processing time by  9 and watermark by 11 then it will test the functionality?
replies.author: rehmanmuradali

replies.bodyText: yes, but you need to advance the watermark before calling addElements.
replies.author: reuvenlax

timeline.bodyText: What about the other getEarliestTimerTimestamp function? Does that need to be updated?
timeline.author: reuvenlax
